name: Hydrogen
uses: Hydrogen is used in the production of ammonia for fertilizers, hydrogenation of oils to make edible fats, and in fuel cells to generate electricity.
interesting_facts: Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, making up about 75% of its normal matter by mass.
Hydrogen's most common isotope, protium, has no neutrons in its nucleus.
The Sun, as well as most stars, is primarily composed of hydrogen, existing in a plasma state.
description: Hydrogen is the chemical element with the symbol H and atomic number 1. With a standard atomic weight of 1.008, hydrogen is the lightest element in the periodic table. Hydrogen is the most abundant chemical substance in the universe, constituting roughly 75% of all baryonic mass. Non-remnant stars are mainly composed of hydrogen in the plasma state. The most common isotope of hydrogen, termed protium, has one proton and no neutrons.

name: Helium
uses: Helium is used in cryogenics, in filling balloons and airships, and as a coolant in superconducting magnets.
interesting_facts: Helium is the second lightest element in the universe and is used in high-pressure gas applications.
It has the lowest boiling and melting points of any element.
description: Helium is the chemical element with the symbol He and atomic number 2. It is the second lightest and second most abundant element in the observable universe. Helium is a colorless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, inert, monatomic gas that heads the noble gases group in the periodic table. It is less dense than air and is used in applications such as cryogenics, airships, and balloons.

name: Lithium
uses: Lithium is used in rechargeable batteries for mobile phones, laptops, electric vehicles, and in the treatment of bipolar disorder.
interesting_facts: Lithium is the lightest metal and is highly reactive, especially with water.
It has the highest specific heat capacity of any solid element.
description: Lithium is the chemical element with the symbol Li and atomic number 3. It is a soft, silvery-white alkali metal and the lightest metal known. Lithium reacts quickly with water and has applications in rechargeable batteries, heat-resistant glass, and medications for mental health disorders.

name: Beryllium
uses: Beryllium is used in aerospace materials for aircraft components, missiles, spacecraft, and satellites due to its light weight and high stiffness.
interesting_facts: Beryllium is a relatively rare element in the universe.
It is toxic and requires careful handling.
description: Beryllium is a chemical element with the symbol Be and atomic number 4. It is a hard, grayish metal naturally found in mineral rocks, coal, soil, and volcanic dust. Beryllium is used in various applications due to its properties, but it is toxic and requires careful handling.

name: Boron
element_discovered_name: Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Louis Jacques Thénard
uses: Boron is used in glass and ceramics, detergents, and as a semiconductor in electronic devices.
interesting_facts: Boron is essential for plant growth.
It has a high melting point and is used in borosilicate glass production.
description: Boron is a chemical element with the symbol B and atomic number 5. It is a metalloid with properties between metals and non-metals. Boron is essential for plant growth and has various industrial applications.

name: Carbon
element_appearance: Varies (e.g., diamond is transparent, graphite is black)
uses: Carbon is used in fuels, steel production, and as a component in plastics and pharmaceuticals.
interesting_facts: Carbon is the fourth most abundant element in the universe by mass.
It forms the basis of all known life on Earth.
description: Carbon is a chemical element with the symbol C and atomic number 6. It is nonmetallic and tetravalent, making four electrons available to form covalent chemical bonds. Carbon is essential to life and has various industrial applications.

name: Nitrogen
uses: Nitrogen is used in fertilizers, explosives, and as a refrigerant in cryogenics.
interesting_facts: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere.
It is a key component of amino acids and proteins, essential for life.
description: Nitrogen is a colorless, odorless gas that is essential to life. It is found in proteins, DNA, and the atmosphere.

name: Oxygen
uses: Oxygen is used in respiration, steelmaking, and medical applications.
interesting_facts: Oxygen makes up about 21% of Earth's atmosphere.
It is the third most abundant element in the universe.
description: Oxygen is an essential element for life and is a major component of water and the Earth's atmosphere.

name: Fluorine
uses: Fluorine is used in toothpaste (fluoride), refrigerants, and non-stick cookware.
interesting_facts: Fluorine is the most electronegative element.
It is highly reactive and can form compounds with almost all elements.
description: Fluorine is a highly reactive, pale yellow gas. It is the most electronegative element and is widely used in various industries.

name: Neon
uses: Neon is used in neon signs, high-voltage indicators, and lasers.
interesting_facts: Neon glows reddish-orange in neon lights.
It is the fifth most abundant element in the universe.
description: Neon is a colorless, odorless noble gas. It is used in lighting and electronic applications due to its bright glow.

name: Sodium
uses: Sodium is used in table salt, soap production, and streetlights.
interesting_facts: Sodium reacts explosively with water.
It is essential for nerve function in humans.
description: Sodium is a soft, silvery-white metal that is highly reactive. It is an essential element in biological processes and has many industrial uses.

name: Magnesium
uses: Magnesium is used in aircraft, fireworks, and medicine.
interesting_facts: Magnesium burns with a bright white flame.
It is essential for photosynthesis in plants.
description: Magnesium is a lightweight metal with high strength. It plays a crucial role in biological processes and is widely used in alloys.

name: Aluminum
uses: Aluminum is used in aircraft, packaging, and construction.
interesting_facts: Aluminum is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust.
It is highly resistant to corrosion due to its oxide layer.
description: Aluminum is a lightweight, corrosion-resistant metal widely used in industrial and consumer applications.

name: Silicon
uses: Silicon is used in semiconductors, solar panels, and glass.
interesting_facts: Silicon is the second most abundant element in Earth's crust.
It is essential for modern electronics.
description: Silicon is a crucial element in technology and industry, forming the basis of semiconductor devices.

name: Phosphorus
uses: Phosphorus is used in fertilizers, matches, and detergents.
interesting_facts: White phosphorus is highly reactive and glows in the dark.
It is essential for DNA and energy transfer in cells.
description: Phosphorus exists in multiple forms and is crucial for life, industry, and agriculture.

name: Sulfur
uses: Sulfur is used in fertilizers, gunpowder, and vulcanization of rubber.
interesting_facts: Sulfur is essential for amino acids and proteins in living organisms.
It is responsible for the smell of rotten eggs.
description: Sulfur is a bright yellow, nonmetallic element that plays an essential role in biological and industrial processes.

name: Chlorine
uses: Chlorine is used in disinfectants, PVC plastic, and water purification.
interesting_facts: Chlorine gas was used as a chemical weapon in World War I.
It is essential for the production of table salt (NaCl).
description: Chlorine is a highly reactive halogen that is crucial for disinfection, chemistry, and biological functions.

name: Argon
uses: Argon is used in light bulbs, welding, and as an inert atmosphere in labs.
interesting_facts: Argon makes up about 1% of Earth's atmosphere.
It is often used in neon lights and lasers.
description: Argon is a colorless, odorless noble gas that is chemically inert and widely used in industry and scientific applications.

name: Potassium
uses: Potassium is used in fertilizers, gunpowder, and dietary supplements.
interesting_facts: Potassium is essential for nerve and muscle function in living organisms.
It reacts violently with water.
description: Potassium is a soft, silvery metal that is essential for biological functions and widely used in agriculture.

name: Calcium
uses: Calcium is used in construction, bone health, and industrial refining.
interesting_facts: Calcium is the most abundant metal in the human body.
It plays a crucial role in muscle contraction and nerve function.
description: Calcium is a vital metal for biological and industrial processes, essential for strong bones and various chemical applications.

name: Scandium
uses: Scandium is used in aerospace components, high-intensity lamps, and aluminum-scandium alloys.
interesting_facts: Scandium is considered a rare earth metal despite not being part of the lanthanide series.
It strengthens aluminum alloys used in aircraft.
description: Scandium is a lightweight, silvery-white transition metal used in aerospace applications and high-performance alloys.

name: Titanium
uses: Titanium is used in aerospace, medical implants, and corrosion-resistant materials.
interesting_facts: Titanium is as strong as steel but 45% lighter.
It is highly resistant to corrosion, even in seawater.
description: Titanium is a strong, corrosion-resistant transition metal widely used in high-performance engineering applications.

name: Vanadium
uses: Vanadium is used in high-strength steel alloys, jet engines, and rechargeable batteries.
interesting_facts: Vanadium steel is extremely strong and used in tools, bridges, and armor plating.
It is essential for some enzymes in biological systems.
description: Vanadium is a transition metal known for its high strength and ability to form strong alloys.

name: Chromium
uses: Chromium is used in stainless steel, chrome plating, and pigments.

name: Manganese
uses: Manganese is used in steel production and batteries.

name: Iron
uses: Iron is used in construction, tools, and machinery.

name: Cobalt
uses: Cobalt is used in rechargeable batteries, magnets, and as a catalyst in chemical reactions.

name: Nickel
uses: Nickel is used in stainless steel, batteries, and coins.

name: Copper
uses: Copper is used in electrical wiring, plumbing, and coinage.

name: Zinc
uses: Zinc is used in galvanization, alloys, and batteries.

name: Gallium
uses: Gallium is used in semiconductors, LED manufacturing, and solar panels. It's also used in some high-temperature thermometers.
interesting_facts: Gallium can melt in your hand as its melting point is just above room temperature (29.8°C)
When it solidifies, it expands by 3.1%
Used in many modern electronics in the form of gallium arsenide
description: Gallium is a chemical element with the symbol Ga and atomic number 31. It is a soft, silvery-blue metal that becomes liquid at slightly above room temperature. Discovered in 1875, it was named after France (Latin: Gallia). Gallium is primarily used in electronics.

name: Germanium
uses: Germanium is used in fiber-optic systems, infrared optics, semiconductor electronics, and solar cell applications.
interesting_facts: It was one of the first semiconductor materials to be used
The first transistor was made from germanium
It is transparent to infrared radiation
description: Germanium is a chemical element with the symbol Ge and atomic number 32. It is a lustrous, hard, grayish-white metalloid in the carbon group. Pure germanium is a semiconductor with an appearance similar to elemental silicon. Like silicon, germanium naturally reacts and forms complexes with oxygen in nature.

name: Arsenic
uses: Arsenic is used in bronzing, pyrotechnics, and for strengthening lead-acid battery grids. It's also used in semiconductors.
interesting_facts: It sublimes (goes directly from solid to gas) when heated
Was used as both a poison and medicine historically
Forms multiple allotropes with different properties
description: Arsenic is a chemical element with the symbol As and atomic number 33. It is a metalloid that occurs in many minerals, usually in combination with sulfur and metals. Arsenic and its compounds are used as pesticides, herbicides, and insecticides, though their use is controversial due to their toxicity.

name: Selenium
uses: Selenium is used in photocells, solar cells, photocopiers, and as a nutritional supplement.
interesting_facts: It exists in several allotropic forms
Essential trace element for humans and animals
Its electrical conductivity increases when exposed to light
description: Selenium is a chemical element with the symbol Se and atomic number 34. It is a nonmetal with properties that are intermediate between the elements above and below in the periodic table, sulfur and tellurium. It rarely occurs in its elemental state or as pure ore compounds in the Earth's crust.

name: Bromine
uses: Bromine is used in flame retardants, water purification, and photographic chemicals.
interesting_facts: Only non-metallic element that is liquid at room temperature
Name comes from Greek word 'bromos' meaning 'stench'
Highly reactive and toxic
description: Bromine is a chemical element with the symbol Br and atomic number 35. It is the third-lightest halogen, and is a fuming red-brown liquid at room temperature that evaporates readily to form a similarly colored gas. Its properties are intermediate between those of chlorine and iodine.

name: Krypton
uses: Krypton is used in certain types of photographic flashes and high-powered gas lasers.
interesting_facts: Used in certain types of lighting and in flash photography
Name comes from Greek 'kryptos' meaning hidden
Was once used to define the meter
description: Krypton is a chemical element with the symbol Kr and atomic number 36. It is a colorless, odorless, tasteless noble gas that occurs in trace amounts in the atmosphere. Krypton, like the other noble gases, is chemically inert and can form stable compounds only with fluorine under special conditions.

name: Rubidium
uses: Rubidium is used in atomic clocks, photocells, and as a getter in vacuum tubes.
interesting_facts: Can ignite spontaneously in air
Discovered spectroscopically through its dark red spectral lines
One of the most electropositive and alkaline elements
description: Rubidium is a chemical element with the symbol Rb and atomic number 37. It is a very soft, silvery-white metal in the alkali metal group. Rubidium is highly reactive, with properties similar to other alkali metals, including rapid oxidation in air and violent reaction with water.

name: Strontium
uses: Strontium is used in fireworks, flares, and in the production of glass for color TV tubes.
interesting_facts: Burns with a bright red flame
Named after the Scottish village of Strontian
Commonly used to produce red colors in fireworks
description: Strontium is a chemical element with the symbol Sr and atomic number 38. An alkaline earth metal, strontium is a soft silver-white yellowish metallic element that is highly reactive chemically. The metal forms a dark oxide layer when exposed to air.

name: Yttrium
uses: Yttrium is used in LED manufacturing, laser technology, and as an additive in various materials to increase strength.
interesting_facts: Named after the village of Ytterby in Sweden
Often used in superconducting materials
Important component in red phosphors used in LED displays
description: Yttrium is a chemical element with symbol Y and atomic number 39. It is a silvery-metallic transition metal chemically similar to the lanthanides and has often been classified as a 'rare-earth element'. Yttrium is almost always found combined with lanthanides in rare-earth minerals.

name: Zirconium
uses: Zirconium is used in nuclear reactors, flash bulbs, surgical appliances, and super alloys.
interesting_facts: Highly resistant to corrosion
Used extensively in nuclear power plants
Found in the gemstone zircon
description: Zirconium is a chemical element with symbol Zr and atomic number 40. The name zirconium is derived from the name of the mineral zircon, the most important source of zirconium. It is a lustrous, grey-white, strong transition metal that resembles hafnium and, to a lesser extent, titanium.

name: Niobium
uses: Niobium is used in steel alloys, superconducting magnets, and jewelry.
interesting_facts: Originally called Columbium
Essential component in superconducting alloys
All its compounds are considered non-toxic
description: Niobium is a chemical element with symbol Nb and atomic number 41. It is a soft, grey, ductile transition metal, often found in the minerals pyrochlore and columbite. Niobium is used in various superconducting materials.

name: Molybdenum
uses: Molybdenum is used in steel alloys, as a catalyst in the petroleum industry, and in fertilizers.
interesting_facts: Essential trace element for all known forms of life
Has the sixth-highest melting point of all elements
Name comes from Greek 'molybdos' meaning lead-like
description: Molybdenum is a chemical element with symbol Mo and atomic number 42. The name is from Neo-Latin molybdaenum, which is based on Ancient Greek Μόλυβδος molybdos, meaning lead, since its ores were confused with lead ores. Molybdenum minerals have been known throughout history, but the element was discovered in 1778 by Carl Wilhelm Scheele.

name: Technetium
uses: Technetium is used primarily in nuclear medicine for diagnostic tests.
interesting_facts: First artificially produced element
No stable isotopes exist
Name means 'artificial' in Greek
description: Technetium is a chemical element with symbol Tc and atomic number 43. It is the lightest element whose isotopes are all radioactive; none are stable. Nearly all technetium is produced synthetically, and only minute amounts are found in the Earth's crust.

name: Ruthenium
uses: Ruthenium is used in electronic components, solar cells, and as a catalyst in chemical reactions.
interesting_facts: Most effective hardener for platinum and palladium
Named after Russia (Ruthenia)
Does not tarnish at room temperature
description: Ruthenium is a chemical element with symbol Ru and atomic number 44. It is a rare transition metal belonging to the platinum group of the periodic table. Like the other metals of the platinum group, ruthenium is inert to most other chemicals.

name: Rhodium
uses: Rhodium is used in catalytic converters, jewelry plating, and as a catalyst in various industrial processes.
interesting_facts: Most expensive precious metal
Named after the Greek word for rose
Highly reflective metal
description: Rhodium is a chemical element with symbol Rh and atomic number 45. It is a rare, silvery-white, hard, corrosion-resistant, and chemically inert transition metal. It is a noble metal and a member of the platinum group.

name: Palladium
uses: Palladium is used in catalytic converters, electronics, dentistry, and jewelry.
interesting_facts: Can absorb up to 900 times its own volume of hydrogen
Named after the asteroid Pallas
Important in hydrogen purification and storage
description: Palladium is a chemical element with symbol Pd and atomic number 46. It is a rare and lustrous silvery-white metal discovered in 1803 by William Hyde Wollaston. He named it after the asteroid Pallas, which was itself named after the epithet of the Greek goddess Athena, acquired by her when she slew Pallas.

name: Silver
uses: Silver is used in jewelry, photography, electrical contacts, and as an antimicrobial agent.
interesting_facts: Has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of any element
Known and used by humans for over 5000 years
Historically used as currency
description: Silver is a chemical element with symbol Ag and atomic number 47. A soft, white, lustrous transition metal, it exhibits the highest electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, and reflectivity of any metal. Most silver is produced as a byproduct of copper, gold, lead, and zinc refining.

name: Cadmium
uses: Cadmium is used in batteries, solar cells, and nuclear reactors.
interesting_facts: Highly toxic and carcinogenic
Named after the mineral cadmia
Used in nuclear reactor control rods
description: Cadmium is a chemical element with symbol Cd and atomic number 48. This soft, silvery-white metal is chemically similar to the two other stable metals in group 12, zinc and mercury. Like zinc, it demonstrates oxidation state +2 in most of its compounds and like mercury it shows a low melting point compared to transition metals.

name: Indium
uses: Indium is used in LCD screens, semiconductors, and solar panels.
interesting_facts: Named for its indigo blue spectral line
Soft enough to be cut with a knife
Critical component in touch screens
description: Indium is a chemical element with symbol In and atomic number 49. It is a post-transition metal that makes up 0.21 parts per million of the Earth's crust. Very soft and silvery-white in color, indium has a melting point higher than sodium and gallium, but lower than lithium and tin.

name: Tin
uses: Tin is used in solder, tin plating, and various alloys.
interesting_facts: One of the earliest metals known to humans
Used in bronze production since 3000 BC
Exists in two different forms (allotropes) at normal pressure
description: Tin is a chemical element with symbol Sn and atomic number 50. It is a post-transition metal in group 14 of the periodic table. It is obtained chiefly from the mineral cassiterite, which contains tin dioxide. Tin shows a chemical similarity to both neighboring group 14 elements, germanium and lead, and has two main oxidation states, +2 and +4.

name: Antimony
uses: Antimony is used in flame-proofing materials, batteries, and alloys.
interesting_facts: Name possibly derived from Greek 'anti-monos', meaning 'not alone'
Used in ancient Egypt as eye makeup
One of the few elements that expands upon freezing
description: Antimony is a chemical element with symbol Sb and atomic number 51. A lustrous gray metalloid, it is found in nature mainly as the sulfide mineral stibnite (Sb2S3). Antimony compounds have been known since ancient times and were used for cosmetics; metallic antimony was also known, but it was erroneously identified as lead.

name: Tellurium
uses: Tellurium is used in solar panels, ceramics, and as a semiconductor in electronics.
interesting_facts: Named after the Latin word for Earth, 'tellus'
One of the rarest stable elements
When burned, produces a greenish-blue flame
description: Tellurium is a chemical element with symbol Te and atomic number 52. It is a silvery-white metalloid which is chemically related to selenium and sulfur. It is occasionally found in native form, but is more often found as the telluride of gold.

name: Iodine
uses: Iodine is used in photography, dye production, and as a nutritional supplement.
interesting_facts: Essential for human nutrition
Sublimes easily into a striking violet vapor
Name comes from Greek 'iodes' meaning violet
description: Iodine is a chemical element with symbol I and atomic number 53. The heaviest of the stable halogens, it exists as a lustrous, purple-pink nonmetal that forms diatomic molecules. Iodine and its compounds are primarily used in nutrition, and industrially in the production of acetic acid and certain polymers.

name: Xenon
uses: Xenon is used in flash lamps, arc lamps, and as an anesthetic.
interesting_facts: First noble gas known to form chemical compounds
Used in ion propulsion systems for spacecraft
Name means 'stranger' in Greek
description: Xenon is a chemical element with symbol Xe and atomic number 54. It is a colorless, dense, odorless noble gas found in the Earth's atmosphere in trace amounts. Although generally unreactive, xenon can undergo a few chemical reactions such as the formation of xenon difluoride.

name: Cesium
uses: Cesium is used in atomic clocks, photoelectric cells, and as a catalyst.
interesting_facts: Most reactive of all metals
Used in the most accurate atomic clocks
Liquid at near room temperature
description: Cesium is a chemical element with symbol Cs and atomic number 55. It is a soft, silvery-golden alkali metal with a melting point of 28.5 °C, which makes it one of only five elemental metals that are liquid at or near room temperature.

name: Barium
uses: Barium is used in X-ray imaging, spark plugs, and in vacuum tubes.
interesting_facts: All water-soluble barium compounds are poisonous
Used in fireworks to produce a green color
Name derives from Greek 'barys' meaning heavy
description: Barium is a chemical element with symbol Ba and atomic number 56. It is the fifth element in Group 2 and is a soft, silvery alkaline earth metal. Because of its high chemical reactivity, barium is never found in nature as a free element.

name: Lanthanum
uses: Lanthanum is used in high-performance optics and hydrogen storage.
interesting_facts: First lanthanide discovered
Essential in many camera lenses
Improves steel malleability and resistance
description: Lanthanum is a chemical element with symbol La and atomic number 57. It is a soft, ductile, silvery-white metal that tarnishes rapidly when exposed to air. It is the first element of the lanthanide series, a group of 15 similar elements between atomic numbers 57 and 71.

name: Cerium
element_discovered_name: Martin Heinrich Klaproth, Jöns Jakob Berzelius, Wilhelm Hisinger
uses: Cerium is used in catalytic converters, self-cleaning ovens, and carbon-arc lighting.
interesting_facts: Most abundant of rare earth elements
Named after dwarf planet Ceres
Used in lighter flints
description: Cerium is a chemical element with symbol Ce and atomic number 58. It is a soft, silvery, ductile metal which easily oxidizes in air. It is the second element in the lanthanide series, following lanthanum. Cerium is the most abundant of the rare earth elements.

name: Praseodymium
uses: Praseodymium is used in magnets, ceramics, and special glasses.
interesting_facts: Name means 'green twin'
Used to make yellow glass for welding goggles
Forms a green oxide coating when exposed to air
description: Praseodymium is a chemical element with symbol Pr and atomic number 59. It is a soft, silvery, malleable and ductile metal, valued for its magnetic, electrical, chemical, and optical properties. It is too reactive to be found in native form, and when artificially prepared, it slowly develops a green oxide coating.

name: Neodymium
uses: Neodymium is used in extremely powerful permanent magnets and lasers.
interesting_facts: Creates the strongest permanent magnets known
Name means 'new twin'
Used in headphones and computer hard drives
description: Neodymium is a chemical element with symbol Nd and atomic number 60. It is a soft silvery metal that tarnishes in air. Neodymium was discovered in 1885 by the Austrian chemist Carl Auer von Welsbach. It is present in significant quantities in the ore minerals monazite and bastnäsite.

name: Promethium
element_discovered_name: Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, Charles D. Coryell
uses: Promethium is used in atomic batteries and as a radioactive tracer.
interesting_facts: Only radioactive lanthanide
Does not occur naturally on Earth
Named after Prometheus from Greek mythology
description: Promethium is a chemical element with symbol Pm and atomic number 61. All of its isotopes are radioactive; it is extremely rare, as the only naturally occurring isotopes are created by the decay of other elements. It was first produced and characterized in 1945.

name: Samarium
uses: Samarium is used in magnets, optical lasers, and nuclear reactors.
interesting_facts: Named after the mineral samarskite
Forms strong magnets with cobalt
Used in cancer treatments
description: Samarium is a chemical element with symbol Sm and atomic number 62. It is a moderately hard silvery metal that readily oxidizes in air. Being a typical member of the lanthanide series, samarium usually assumes the oxidation state +3.

name: Europium
uses: Europium is used in phosphors for TV screens, LED lights, and anti-counterfeiting measures in banknotes.

name: Gadolinium
uses: Gadolinium is used in MRI contrast agents, nuclear reactors, and compact discs.

name: Terbium
uses: Terbium is used in green phosphors for TVs and LEDs, as well as in solid-state devices.

name: Dysprosium
uses: Dysprosium is used in nuclear reactors, magnets, and data storage applications.

name: Holmium
uses: Holmium is used in nuclear reactors, lasers, and magnets.

name: Erbium
uses: Erbium is used in fiber optics, lasers, and nuclear reactor control rods.

name: Thulium
uses: Thulium is used in portable X-ray machines and lasers.

name: Ytterbium
uses: Ytterbium is used in fiber optics, and in certain lasers and alloying.

name: Lutetium
uses: Lutetium is used in positron emission tomography (PET) scanners and as a catalyst in petroleum refining.

name: Hafnium
element_discovered_name: George Charles de Hevesy and Dirk Coster
uses: Hafnium is used in nuclear reactors and in the aerospace industry.

name: Tantalum
uses: Tantalum is used in electronics, capacitors, and in the aerospace industry.

name: Tungsten
uses: Tungsten is used in light bulb filaments, electronics, and in manufacturing high-strength alloys.

name: Rhenium
uses: Rhenium is used in high-temperature superalloys and in thermocouples.

name: Osmium
uses: Osmium is used in fountain pen nibs, electrical contacts, and in various chemical applications.

name: Iridium
uses: Iridium is used in spark plugs, electrical contacts, and in catalysis.

name: Platinum
uses: Platinum is used in jewelry, catalysts, and in laboratory equipment.

name: Gold
uses: Gold is used in jewelry, electronics, and as a form of currency.

name: Mercury
uses: Mercury is used in thermometers, barometers, and in some chemical processes.

name: Thallium
uses: Thallium is used in electronics and as a component in some specialized alloys.

name: Lead
uses: Lead is used in batteries, radiation shielding, and in the construction industry.

name: Bismuth
uses: Bismuth is used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and as an alloy in fire detectors.

name: Polonium
uses: Polonium is used in nuclear research and as a heat source in space equipment.

name: Astatine
element_discovered_name: Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, Emilio Segrè
element_appearance: Metallic or non-metallic, depending on the allotrope
uses: Astatine is used in targeted alpha-particle cancer therapy.

name: Radon
uses: Radon is used in cancer treatment and in radon therapy.

name: Francium
uses: Francium is used in research related to atomic behavior but is too rare and unstable for practical use.

name: Radium
uses: Radium was historically used in luminous paint for dials and watches but is now largely replaced due to radioactivity.

name: Actinium
uses: Actinium is used as a neutron source in radiation therapy and scientific research.

name: Thorium
uses: Thorium is used in nuclear reactors and as an alloy to increase strength in materials.

name: Protactinium
uses: Protactinium is used in research and in the production of nuclear energy.

name: Uranium
uses: Uranium is used as fuel in nuclear reactors and for the production of nuclear weapons.

name: Neptunium
element_discovered_name: Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur C. Wahl, and Joseph W. Kennedy
uses: Neptunium is used in the production of plutonium-238 and as a neutron source in research.

name: Plutonium
element_discovered_name: Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur C. Wahl, and Joseph W. Kennedy
uses: Plutonium is used in nuclear weapons, nuclear reactors, and as a heat source for spacecraft.

name: Americium
element_discovered_name: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, and Leon O. Morgan
uses: Americium is used in smoke detectors and in radiation therapy.

name: Curium
element_discovered_name: Glenn T. Seaborg, Albert Ghiorso, and Glenn T. Seaborg
uses: Curium is used in scientific research, and as a heat source for spacecraft.

name: Berkelium
element_discovered_name: Glenn T. Seaborg, Albert Ghiorso, and Glenn T. Seaborg
uses: Berkelium is used in scientific research, particularly in the creation of heavier elements.

name: Californium
element_discovered_name: Glenn T. Seaborg, Albert Ghiorso, and Glenn T. Seaborg
uses: Californium is used in nuclear reactors and as a neutron source in medical and industrial applications.

name: Einsteinium
element_discovered_name: Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg, and others
uses: Einsteinium is used in scientific research, particularly in the creation of heavier elements.

name: Fermium
element_discovered_name: Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg, and others
uses: Fermium is used in scientific research, particularly in nuclear reactions.

name: Mendelevium
element_discovered_name: Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg, and others
uses: Mendelevium is used in scientific research, particularly in nuclear reactions.

name: Nobelium
